parcel.name: PLATESPACE | 盘子空间
parcel.label: gallery
parcel.description:
描述：PLATESPACE成立于2018年，空间依据不同语境邀请艺术家实施艺术项目。
PLATESPACE, established in 2018, presents art projects derived from specific contexts.

features.text:
#The Chomsky - Foucault - Orange Juice Debate 1971
###03:36  
03:37
Ladies and gentlemen,
03:39
welcome to the fourth debate of the International Philosophers' Project.
03:44
Tonight's debaters are Mr. Michel Foucault of the College de France
03:51
and Mr. Noam Chomsky of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
03:59
Both philosophers have points in common and points of difference.
04:04
Perhaps the best way to compare both philosophers
04:08
would be to see them as mountain-diggers working at opposite sides
04:14
of the same mountain with different tools, without even knowing
04:19
if they are working in each other's direction.
04:22
All studies of humanity, ranging from history to linguistics and psychology,
04:29
are faced with the question of whether in the last instance,
04:34
we are the product of all kinds of external factors
###04:37 
04:38
or if, in spite of our differences, we have something we could call
04:43
a common human nature by which we can call each other human beings.
04:48
So my first question is to Mr. Chomsky,
04:51
because you often employ the concept of human nature
04:55
in which connection you even use terms like "innate ideas" and "innate structures".
05:01
Which arguments can you derive from linguistics
05:05
in order to give such a central position to this notion of human nature?
05:12
Well, let me begin in a slightly technical way.
05:19
A person who is interested in studying languages
05:22
is faced with a very definite empirical problem.
05:26
He's faced with an organism, a mature, let's say adult speaker,
05:32
who has somehow acquired an amazing range of abilities,
05:38
which enable him in particular to say what he means,
05:43
to understand what people say to him,
05:45
to do this in a fashion that I think is proper to call highly creative.
05:50
Now, the person who has acquired this intricate and highly articulated
05:56
and organized collection of abilities
05:59
-- the collection of abilities that we call knowing a language --
06:02
that person has been exposed to a certain experience; he has been presented
06:08
in the course of his lifetime with a certain amount of data,
06:13
of direct experience with a language.
06:14
We can investigate the data that's available to this person; having done so,
06:21
in principle, we're faced with a reasonably clear and well-delineated scientific problem,
06:29
namely that of accounting for the gap between the really quite small quantity of data, small
06:38
and rather degenerate quantity of data that's presented to the person, to the child, and
06:43
the very highly articulated, highly systematic, profoundly organized resulting knowledge that
06:51
he somehow derives from this data.
06:53
Furthermore -- even more remarkable -- we notice that in a wide range of languages,
06:59
in fact all that have been studied seriously, there are remarkable limitations
07:05
on the kinds of systems that emerge from the very different kinds
07:09
of experience to which people are exposed.
07:13
There is only one possible explanation, which I have to give in a rather schematic fashion,
07:19
for this remarkable phenomenon, namely the assumption
07:25
that the individual himself contributes a good deal, an overwhelming part in fact,
07:35
of the general schematic structure and perhaps even of the specific content of the knowledge
07:41
that he ultimately derives from this very scattered and limited experience. That is,
07:47
to put it rather loosely: the child must begin with the knowledge, certainly not with the
07:52
knowledge that he's hearing English or Dutch or French or something else, but he does start
###07:55 
07:57
with the knowledge that he's hearing a human language of a very narrow and explicit type,
08:02
that permits a very small range of variation. And it's because he begins with that highly
08:07
organized and very restrictive schematism, that he is able to make the huge leap from
08:13
scattered and degenerate data to highly organized knowledge.
08:18
I would claim then that this instinctive knowledge, if you like,
08:23
this schematism that makes it possible to derive complex and intricate
08:28
knowledge on the basis of very partial data, is one fundamental constituent of human nature.
###08:33 
08:34
And I assume that in other domains of human intelligence, in other domains of human cognition
08:40
and even behavior, something of the same sort must be true.
###08:43 
08:46
Well, the collection, this mass of schematisms, innate organizing principles
08:53
which guides our social and intellectual and individual behavior,
08:58
that's what I mean to refer to by the concept of human nature.
###09:02 
09:04
Well, Mr. Foucault, when I think of your books like
###09:09 
09:09
The History of Madness and Words and Objects, I get the impression that you are
09:14
working on a completely different level and with an opposite aim and goal;
###09:18 
09:22
when I think of the word 'schematism' in relation to human nature
09:27
I suppose you are trying to elaborate
09:29
several periods, several schematisms. What do you think about this?
09:36
Well if you permit, I will answer in French
09:38
because my English is so bad that I would be ashamed of answering in English.
09:45
It is true that I mistrust the notion of human nature a little.
09:53
And for the following reason: I believe that of the concepts
10:02
or notions that a science can use, not all have the same degree of elaboration.
10:16
Let's take the example of biology. Within the field of biology
10:23
there are concepts that are more or less well established, like the concept of a "reflex".
10:29
But there also exist peripheral notions, which do not play an "organizing" role within science,
10:45
they are not instruments of analysis and they are not descriptive either. These notions
10:54
simply serve to point out some problems, or rather to point out certain fields in need of study.
11:04
For instance, there exists a very important concept in the field of biology:
###11:11 
11:11
the concept of life. In the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries, the notion of life was
11:24
hardly used when studying nature: one classified natural beings, whether living or non-living,
11:31
in a vast hierarchical tableau. Life was a concept they didn't use and didn't need.
11:40
At the end of the eighteenth century a number of problems arose, for instance in relation
11:47
to the internal organization of these natural beings. Moreover, thanks to the use of the
11:57
microscope, different sorts of phenomena and mechanisms that had been unclear in the past
12:07
and could not have been perceived until then suddenly came to light.
12:12
The developments in chemistry have also highlighted certain problems in relation
12:18
to the connections between chemical reactions and the physiological processes of organisms.
12:25
And that's how an entire field appeared,
12:27
one that was completely new for biologists, one that is nowadays known as life.
12:35
Life was a concept that served to point out new fields of study that science still
###12:43 
12:44
had to discover. I would say, as a historian of science, that the concept of life was an
12:52
epistemological indicator; an index of the problems that still had to be uncovered.
12:58
And I ask myself whether perhaps one could say the same thing about human nature.
13:04
Foucault is therefore comparing Chomsky's concept of human nature
13:08
with the concept of life as used in biology and in the history of that science.
13:12
He does this because his sees of the concept of human nature
13:16
more as an indication of a research program
13:20
rather than as an indication of humanity's potential for achievement.
13:26
For him, human nature acts as a scientific shopping list and nothing more.
13:32
Chomsky is willing to accept this as long as it is clear that the fields
13:37
of biology, physiology and neurology still don't have the means
13:42
to adequately describe human nature and humanity's capacity for language.
13:48
Quite early on in the debate, moderator Mr. Elders
13:54
finds it difficult to keep the interaction flowing between the two speakers.
13:58
This is partly due to the different languages they speak, but most importantly due to the
14:03
fact that Chomsky and Foucault inhabit such different worlds of thought, to the point
14:10
in which their ideas easily slide past each other. We actually observe the curious phenomenon
14:15
of two brains thinking simultaneously, where one picks up the last claim of the other in
14:23
order to further elucidate it from his own system of thought.
14:28
For Chomsky the concept of creativity plays an important role,
14:33
and the following part of the debate will be largely dedicated to this issue.
14:36
For Chomsky creativity is actually acharacteristic of all human beings.
14:41
Everybody uses it. People stuck in traffic who unexpectedly and on the spot,
14:46
have to think about what to do next.
14:48
The educator who doesn't want to fall into a pattern of authoritarian behavior
14:53
and when confronted with a difficult pupil, has to invent new behavior.
14:57
But above all, this creativity applies to the child
15:01
who learns a language and who curiously learns to produce new language.
15:11
Foucault is opposed to this idea. He constantly emphasizes
15:14
the so-called "epistemological field" within which human activity takes place.
15:22
This "epistemological field" or "épistèmè"
15:26
is described as the totality of unconscious rules
15:31
that manage the totality of all separated fields of knowledge.
15:37
Foucault also talks of "tableau", and also calls it "system of elements",
15:43
and in the debate the word "grille" is mentioned: bar or grid.
15:47
Perhaps it's best to speak of a network within which everybody in
15:52
a particular culture thinks whether they want it or not.
15:54
It is a certain set of rules to which everybody's thinking obeys
15:59
and with which people search for identity, coherency and so forth.
16:05
This system is not a creation of particular individuals:
16:11
it decides the rules of the "think-and-do" habits we call culture, which every individual
16:19
is subjected to. Such a system is not a thing or idea, but lies precisely in between these.
16:29
For Foucault the history of thought is not be associated with the history of ideas
16:33
or even of the development of the mind,
16:37
but rather it should be understood as discontinuous transformations.
16:44
transitioning from one network to another.
16:47
That is a totally different approach from that of Chomsky,
16:51
for whom creativity plays a central role. At this point we encounter
16:56
Foucault's dethroning of the subject, as already illustrated with the example of Galilei.
17:05
The philosophy of Foucault is a philosophy in which the philosopher
17:09
constantly disappears from sight.
17:12
One could say that, paradoxically, it is a philosophy without philosophers:
17:17
an idea to be generalized because humans are, according to Foucault, greatly absent
17:24
within their own culture. In this respect, Foucault's strong and negative reaction
17:32
towards the moderator who showed interest in private matters of his life.
17:38
When Foucault debates, it is about everything except Foucault himself.
17:43
This is an introduction to the following -- quite detailed -- theoretical part of the debate
17:49
which seems to mainly focus on one question:
17:54
to what extent is the individual able to discover something new,
17:59
and if so, how should we make sense of this? This seems to me to a very relevant question,
18:06
especially if we remind ourselves that we need quiet some new forms
18:11
of behavior, knowledge and science if we want to survive together in this world.
18:19
We resume the debate where Foucault explains why he doesn't pay much attention
18:25
to the creativity of the individual from a historical perspective.
18:31
Within the traditional history of science,
18:33
the creativity of individuals has been accorded maximum importance. The history of science,
18:44
up until recently, essentially consisted of showing how an individual -- whether it was
###18:47 
18:52
Newton or Mendel -- had been the creator, or rather the discoverer of a reality that
18:59
was already existing in things and in the world, a reality that no other person had
19:09
previously discovered. I believe the postulate that lies at the core of the traditional history
19:16
of science is that truth exists in order to be known; yet the human mind, due to the effect
19:28
of a number of inhibitions or obstacles, has not managed to see this truth. The mind is
19:37
made to see the truth and a contingent obstacle is impeding him to see it. According to some
19:46
historians, this obstacle could be linked to socio-economic conditions, or to different
19:49
forms of mentality, or to the belief and naivety in old religious myths and moral themes.
19:57
All of these could act as obstacles, as blinders to those who want to see the truth. In reality,
20:07
the mind is meant to see, it is made to have access to the truth. In this traditional conception
20:14
of the history of science, on the one hand there is an emphasis on the creativity of
20:21
the individual who has the right to possess the truth, and yet a system of obstacles will
20:30
prevent him from capturing, formulating and constructing this truth to which he is essentially
20:40
entitled to possess. I believe the problem that is being posed is the exact opposite.
20:47
What happens when we witness a great scientific transformation? In a great scientific
transformation
###20:52 
20:57
-- for instance the birth of biology mid seventeenth century, or the birth of philology
21:04
at the end of the eighteenth and the beginning of the nineteenth century -- it is true that
21:08
a number of obstacles, prejudices, preconceived ideas tumble and disappear. What strikes me,
21:16
however, is that science, at the moment of its birth, not only gets rid of a certain
###21:20 
21:24
number of obstacles but also eliminates and masks a certain amount of existing knowledge.
21:34
It's as if applying a new grid, which allows for the appearance of phenomena
21:44
that had been previously masked while at the same time masking already existing knowledge.
21:49
Therefore, a science, the advancement of science and the acquisition of science, is not simply
21:55
the oblivion of old prejudices, or the fall of certain obstacles. It is a new grid that
22:01
masks certain things while allowing for the appearance of new knowledge. Therefore, when
22:06
I criticize the notion of creativity, what I mean is that truth is not acquired through
22:14
a kind of continuous and cumulative creation, but rather through a set of grids stacked
22:20
on top of one other, which leak old and collect new knowledge.
22:24
I think in part we're slightly talking at cross-purposes,
22:27
because of a different use of the term creativity. In fact, I should say that
22:31
my use of the term creativity is a little bit idiosyncratic
22:36
and therefore the onus falls on me and not on you in this case.
22:39
But when I speak of creativity, I'm not attributing
22:44
to the concept, the notion of value that is normal when we speak of creativity.
22:52
That is, when you speak of scientific creativity,
22:56
you're speaking, properly, of the achievements of a Newton.
22:59
But in the context in which I have been speaking about creativity,
23:03
it's a normal human event.
23:05
I'm speaking of the kind of creativity that any child demonstrates when he's able
23:15
to come to grips with a new situation: to describe it properly, react to it properly,
23:22
tell one something about it, think about it in a new fashion for him and so on.
23:28
I think it's appropriate to call those creative acts,
23:32
but of course without thinking of those acts as being the acts of a Newton.
###23:35 
23:36
It's the lower levels of creativity that I've been speaking of.
23:40
Now, as far as what you say about the history of science is concerned, I think
23:44
that's correct, illuminating and particularly relevant in fact to the kinds of enterprise
23:50
that I see lying before us in psychology, linguistics and the philosophy of the mind.
23:57
That is, I think there are certain topics that have been, in your words, repressed
24:03
or put aside during the scientific advances of the past few centuries.
24:10
But now, I think, we can overcome those,
24:14
it is possible to put aside those limitations and forgettings, and to
24:19
bring into our consideration precisely the topics that animated a good deal of
24:24
the thinking and speculation of the seventeenth and eighteenth century,
24:28
and to incorporate them within a much broader and I think deeper
24:31
science of man that will give a fuller role
24:39
-- though certainly not expected to give a complete understanding to such notions as
24:45
innovation and creativity, freedom and production of new elements of
###24:49 
24:57
thought and behavior within some system of rule and schematism.
25:01
Those are concepts that I think we can come to grips with.
25:03
In reality, I believe there is a quite strong similarity
###25:05 
25:06
between what Mr. Chomsky said and what I tried to show:
25:09
in other words there exist in fact only possible creations, possible innovations.
25:18
One can only, in terms of language or of knowledge,
25:22
produce something new by putting into play a certain number of rules
###25:29 
25:30
which will define the acceptability or grammaticality of these statements, or which
25:38
will define, in the case of knowledge, the scientific character of the statements.
25:44
Thus, we can roughly say that linguists before Mr. Chomsky mainly insisted on
25:50
the rules of construction of statements and less on the innovation
25:59
represented by every new statement, or the hearing of a new statement.
26:05
And in the history of science or in the history of thought,
26:08
we placed more emphasis on individual creation
###26:10 
26:13
and we had kept aside and left in the shadows these communal,
26:22
general rules, which obscurely manifest themselves through
26:27
every scientific discovery, every scientific invention,
26:32
and even every philosophical innovation. These are not only linguistic rules
###26:35 
26:36
but also epistemological rules, which characterize contemporary knowledge.
26:41
Well I think... Perhaps I can try to react to those comments
26:46
within my own framework in a way which will maybe shed some light on this.
26:50
How is it that we are able to construct any kind of scientific theory at all?
26:54
How is it that, given a small amount of data, it's possible for various scientists,
27:00
for various geniuses even, over a long period of time,
27:04
to arrive at some kind of a theory, at least in some cases,
27:07
that is more or less profound and more or less empirically adequate?
###27:09 
27:11
This is a remarkable fact.
27:12
And, in fact, if it were not the case that these scientists, including the geniuses,
27:18
if they didn't have built into their minds somehow an obviously unconscious
27:24
specification of what is a possible scientific theory,
27:28
then this inductive leap would certainly be quite impossible:
27:31
just as if each child did not have built into his mind
27:35
the concept of human language in a very narrowing way,
27:39
then the inductive leap from data to knowledge of a language would be impossible.
27:44
So even though the process of, let's say, deriving knowledge of physics from data
###27:48 
27:50
is far more complex, far more difficult for an organism such as us,
27:55
far more drawn out in time, requiring intervention of genius and so on and so forth,
27:59
nevertheless in a certain sense the achievement of discovering physical science
28:06
or biology or whatever you like, is based on something rather similar
28:11
to the achievement of the normal child in discovering the structure of his language:
28:15
that is, it must be achieved on the basis of an initial limitation,
28:19
an initial restriction on the class of possible theories.
28:23
And the fact that science converges and progresses
28:26
shows us that such initial limitations and structures exist.
28:30
That is, I don't think that scientific progress is simply a matter of
28:34
accumulative addition of new knowledge and the absorption of new theories and so on.
28:41
Rather I think that it has this sort of jagged pattern that you describe,
28:46
forgetting certain problems and leaping to new theories.
28:49
And transforming the same knowledge.
28:51
Right. But I think that one can perhaps hazard an explanation for that fact.
28:58
Oversimplifying grossly, I really don't mean what I'm going to say now literally,
29:03
it is as if, as human beings of a particular biologically given organism,
29:08
we have in our heads, to start with, a certain set of possible intellectual structures,
29:15
possible sciences. Okay? Now, in the lucky event that some aspect of reality
29:21
happens to have the character of one of these structures in our mind, then we have a science.
29:27
And it is because of this initial limitation in our minds to a certain kind of possible science
29:36
that provides the tremendous richness and creativity of scientific knowledge.
29:41
It is important to stress -- and this has to do with your point about limitation and freedom
29:47
-- if it were not for these limitations, we would not have the creative act of going
29:53
from a little bit of knowledge, a little bit of experience, to a rich and highly articulated
29:58
and complicated array of knowledge. It is precisely because of this that the progress
30:01
of science has the erratic and jagged and transformational character that you described.
30:09
And that doesn't mean everything is ultimately going to fall within the domain of science.
30:13
Quite the contrary. Personally I believe that
30:16
many of the things we would like to understand,
30:19
and maybe the things we would most like to understand,
30:21
such as the nature of man, or the nature of a decent society,
30:26
or lots of other things, might really fall outside the scope of possible human science.
30:30
Well I think we have now two questions out of this statement.
30:35
One question is: Mr. Foucault, if you agree with the statement about
30:41
the combination of limitation, fundamental limitation?
30:44
It is not a matter of combination.
30:45
Creativity only becomes possible thanks to a system of rules:
30:53
it is not a mixture of order and freedom.
30:58
Freedom can only be truly exercised thanks to a system of regularity.
31:06
Where perhaps I don't completely agree with Mr. Chomsky is
31:13
when he places these regularities within the sphere of the human mind or human nature.
31:22
I would like to know whether one cannot discover this system of regularity and of constraint
31:27
-- which makes science possible -- somewhere else, even outside the human mind:
31:34
in social forms, in relations of production, in class struggles, etc.
31:40
But what does this theory of knowledge mean for your theme of the death of man
31:46
or the end of the period of the nineteenth and twentieth centuries?
31:52
But this is not related to what we are talking about?
31:55
I don't know, because I was trying to apply what you have said
32:04
in relation to your anthropological concept. You have already refused to speak
32:10
about your own creativity and freedom, haven't you?
32:13
Well, I'm wondering what are the psychological reasons for this.
32:19
Well, you can wonder about it, but I can't help that?
32:21
But what are the objective reasons, in relation to your perception of understanding,
32:30
of knowledge, of science, for refusing to answer these personal questions?
32:36
Does it have to do with your conception of society?
32:42
When there is a problem for you to answer:
32:46
what are your reasons for making a problem out of a personal question?
32:50
No, I'm not making a problem out of a personal question;
32:53
I make of a personal question an absence of a problem.
32:56
In the entire tradition of the history of thought, ideas and sciences,
###33:01 
33:03
one has always questioned the problem of knowing.
33:06
At what age was Newton weaned into conceiving the universal law of gravity?
33:13
At which period did Cuvier meet his first mistress
33:18
in order to finally discover fossils and comparative anatomy, etc?
33:23
I believe these types of analyses, which I am now simplifying, are not very interesting.
33:30
On the other hand, it is much more interesting to understand the transformations of a certain
###33:34 
33:36
knowledge within the general field of science and within the so-called vertical field
33:45
which consists of a society, a culture, a civilization at a particular moment in time.
33:50
Once we finally grasp the totality of this transformation,
33:54
we realize that the little individual moments of a wise man's life are not important.
34:01
Again Foucault's last comment suggests how the individual life
34:07
of the researcher tends to disappear from sight.
34:09
But how do we explain then the relation of man in relation to its culture in politics
34:17
and maybe even the question about how to change this culture and society?
34:19
After all one can show within the history of science and culture,
34:24
the input of the individual is almost negligible,
34:29
the question 'how do I act?' -- the political question - remains standing.
34:36
It may thus become clear by now that this political question, from Foucault's perspective,
34:43
rapidly develops into "how far can mankind escape from its own culture?"
34:50
It is important to note that Foucault doesn't want to distance himself from politics.
34:56
In the contrary, he says "I would have to be ideologically blind
35:01
to not interest myself for that which is most substantial to human existence:
35:06
economic relations, power relations, you name it".
35:10
Therefore, Chomsky and Foucault do agree on the importance of the political question.
35:12
In his opinion, it is required to abolish and destroy the different forms of capitalism
35:13
in order to favor direct workers' participation
35:15
It may also be informative to explicitly mention that Chomsky defines his political standpoint
35:23
as anarcho-syndicalism.
35:35
in workers' councils and so on. Decentralization, socialization and participation
35:42
are keywords in Chomsky's political program.
35:46
Chomsky might say he sees no obvious relation between his scientific and political views,
35:52
but the following opening statement reveals
35:55
that he heads straight from his scientific conceptions to politics.
36:01
His political and scientific views may not flow logically one from the other,
###36:05 
36:06
they do certainly head in the same direction.
36:09
Let me begin by referring to something that we have already discussed,
36:13
that is, if it is correct, as I believe it is, that a fundamental element of human nature
36:20
is the need for creative work, for creative inquiry, for free creation
36:29
without the arbitrary limiting effect of coercive institutions,
36:36
then, of course it will follow that a decent society should maximize the possibilities
36:43
for this fundamental human characteristic to be realized.
36:47
That means trying to overcome the elements of repression and oppression
36:55
and destruction and coercion that exist in any existing society, ours for example,
37:02
as a historical residue. Now a federated, decentralized system of free associations,
37:13
incorporating economic as well as social institutions,
37:17
would be what I refer to as anarcho-syndicalism;
37:20
and it seems to me that this is the appropriate form of social organization for an advanced
37:26
technological society, in which human beings do not have to be forced into the position
37:32
of tools, of cogs in the machine. In which the creative urge that I think is intrinsic
37:39
to human nature, will in fact be able to realize itself in whatever way it will, I don't
37:43
know all the ways in which it will.
37:45
I would say that I am much less advanced than Mr. Chomsky in this respect.
37:51
That is, I admit not being able to define, not even to propose,
38:02
an ideal social model for the functioning of our scientific or technological society.
38:11
On the other hand, one of the tasks that seems immediate and urgent to me,
38:17
over and above anything else, is this: it is the custom, at least in our European society,
###38:18 
38:26
to consider that power is localized in the hands of the government
38:32
and that it is exercised through a certain number of particular institutions,
38:37
such as the administration, the police or the army.
38:46
One knows that all these institutions are made to transmit and apply orders
38:51
